MainCategory.Description: Technical Proficiency: Assesses the candidate's depth and breadth of technical skills, including programming languages, frameworks, databases, and relevant technologies, aligning with the job's requirements.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Review the candidate's resume and experience, scrutinizing the listed technologies and projects. Assess their familiarity with C#, .NET, SQL, JavaScript, HTML, CSS, and other relevant technologies. Ask targeted technical questions to evaluate their understanding and problem-solving abilities. Review code samples if available.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Candidate demonstrates minimal to no proficiency in required technologies.
Candidate possesses basic knowledge but lacks practical experience.
Candidate is proficient in some required technologies but has gaps in others.
Candidate is highly proficient in most required technologies and demonstrates practical experience.
Candidate is an expert in all required technologies and has extensive practical experience, potentially exceeding expectations.

MainCategory.Description: Problem-Solving Skills: Evaluates the candidate's ability to analyze complex issues, identify root causes, and develop effective solutions, as evidenced by their experience and approach to challenges.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Pose scenario-based questions that require the candidate to troubleshoot and solve technical problems. Assess their approach to problem-solving, their ability to think critically, and their attention to detail. Inquire about past experiences where they had to overcome technical challenges.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Candidate struggles to analyze problems and propose solutions.
Candidate can identify problems but struggles to develop effective solutions.
Candidate can analyze problems and propose basic solutions, but may lack depth.
Candidate demonstrates strong problem-solving skills and can develop effective solutions.
Candidate is an exceptional problem-solver who can analyze complex issues and develop innovative solutions.

MainCategory.Description: Communication and Collaboration: Measures the candidate's ability to communicate effectively with both technical and non-technical stakeholders and to collaborate effectively within a team environment, as emphasized in the job description.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Assess the candidate's communication skills through direct interaction. Observe their ability to articulate technical concepts clearly and concisely. Ask questions about their experience working in teams and their approach to conflict resolution. Check references to validate their collaborative skills.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Candidate struggles to communicate effectively and collaborate with others.
Candidate can communicate basic information but struggles to collaborate effectively.
Candidate communicates adequately and can collaborate in a limited capacity.
Candidate communicates effectively and collaborates well within a team.
Candidate is an exceptional communicator and collaborator who fosters a positive team environment.

MainCategory.Description: Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) Knowledge: Evaluates the candidate's understanding and experience with the various phases of the software development lifecycle, ensuring they can contribute effectively throughout the entire process.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Ask questions about the candidate's experience with different SDLC methodologies (e.g., Agile, Waterfall). Assess their understanding of requirements gathering, design, development, testing, deployment, and maintenance. Inquire about their ability to create technical documentation and test plans. Examine past project involvement for depth of SDLC exposure.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Candidate has limited to no understanding of the software development lifecycle.
Candidate has a basic understanding of the SDLC but lacks practical experience.
Candidate is familiar with some phases of the SDLC but has gaps in others.
Candidate has a strong understanding of the SDLC and practical experience in most phases.
Candidate is an expert in the SDLC and has extensive experience in all phases, contributing significantly to project success.

SubCategory.Description: C# and .NET Framework Proficiency: Assesses the candidate's expertise in C# and the .NET framework, crucial for development in the primary software development platform.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Evaluate the candidate's resume for specific projects and experiences using C# and .NET. Ask technical questions about C# syntax, .NET libraries, and object-oriented programming principles. Request code samples to assess their coding style and problem-solving abilities within the .NET ecosystem.

ScoringGuided.Comment: No experience or knowledge of C# and .NET.
Basic understanding of C# and .NET syntax.
Familiar with C# and .NET, can perform basic tasks.
Proficient in C# and .NET, can develop complex applications.
Expert in C# and .NET, deep understanding of the framework.

SubCategory.Description: Database Technologies (SQL Server, T-SQL): Evaluates the candidate's skills in database technologies, specifically Microsoft SQL Server and T-SQL, essential for managing and querying data.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Review the candidate's experience with SQL Server and T-SQL. Ask questions about database design, query optimization, and stored procedure development. Present database-related scenarios and assess their ability to write efficient SQL queries and troubleshoot database issues.

ScoringGuided.Comment: No experience or knowledge of SQL Server and T-SQL.
Basic understanding of SQL concepts.
Familiar with SQL Server and T-SQL, can write basic queries.
Proficient in SQL Server and T-SQL, can design databases and optimize queries.
Expert in SQL Server and T-SQL, deep understanding of database administration.

SubCategory.Description: Web Technologies (JavaScript, HTML, CSS): Assesses the candidate's competence in web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, enabling them to contribute to front-end development and user interface design.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Assess the candidate's knowledge of JavaScript, HTML, and CSS through their portfolio or projects. Ask questions about web development principles, responsive design, and front-end frameworks. Present web-related challenges and assess their ability to create interactive and user-friendly web interfaces.

ScoringGuided.Comment: No experience or knowledge of JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.
Basic understanding of HTML and CSS syntax.
Familiar with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, can create basic web pages.
Proficient in JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, can develop interactive web applications.
Expert in JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, deep understanding of front-end frameworks.

SubCategory.Description: Agile Development Experience: Measures the candidate's familiarity with Agile methodologies, crucial for collaborative and iterative software development.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Inquire about the candidate's experience working in Agile environments. Ask about their familiarity with Scrum, Kanban, or other Agile frameworks. Assess their understanding of Agile principles, such as iterative development, collaboration, and continuous improvement. Determine their contribution to Agile teams and their ability to adapt to changing requirements.

ScoringGuided.Comment: No experience with Agile development methodologies.
Aware of Agile principles but no practical experience.
Some experience with Agile, participated in Scrum meetings.
Proficient in Agile, understands Scrum and Kanban.
Expert in Agile, can lead Agile teams and implement best practices.

SubCategory.Description: Troubleshooting Skills: Assesses the candidate's ability to diagnose and resolve technical issues, a critical skill for maintaining and improving software systems.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Provide the candidate with hypothetical scenarios involving software bugs or system failures. Assess their ability to analyze the problem, identify potential causes, and propose solutions. Evaluate their approach to debugging, their use of troubleshooting tools, and their attention to detail. Check references regarding their problem-solving abilities.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Unable to identify or troubleshoot technical problems.
Limited troubleshooting skills, requires significant assistance.
Can troubleshoot basic issues with guidance.
Proficient in troubleshooting, can independently resolve most issues.
Expert troubleshooter, can quickly diagnose and resolve complex problems.
